stages.title: Not All Questions Are Equal
stages.description: Discover why some questions can be investigated scientifically while others cannot.

activities.title: ü§î The Question Challenge
activities.content: A student asks: 'Which tastes better, chocolate or vanilla ice cream?' Their teacher says this isn't a scientific question. Another student asks: 'Which ice cream melts faster at 25¬∞C, chocolate or vanilla?' The teacher says this IS a scientific question. What's the difference? The answer will transform how you think about science!

activities.title: What Makes a Question Scientific?
activities.description: Watch this video to understand the difference between testable and non-testable questions.

activities.title: üî¨ Testable vs Non-Testable Questions
activities.content:
**Testable Questions** (Scientific):
‚Ä¢ Can be answered through investigation and measurement
‚Ä¢ Have measurable, observable outcomes
‚Ä¢ Can be tested with evidence
‚Ä¢ Different people doing the same test get similar results

Examples:
‚Ä¢ Does temperature affect how fast sugar dissolves?
‚Ä¢ Which material is the strongest?
‚Ä¢ How does exercise affect heart rate?

**Non-Testable Questions** (Opinion-based):
‚Ä¢ Based on personal preference or beliefs
‚Ä¢ Cannot be measured or observed objectively
‚Ä¢ No clear evidence can settle the answer
‚Ä¢ Different people will have different answers based on opinion

Examples:
‚Ä¢ Which color is the prettiest?
‚Ä¢ What's the best music genre?
‚Ä¢ Should we explore space?

activities.title: Helping Your Friend
activities.situation: Your friend Emma wants to do a science fair project. She's passionate about environmental issues and comes to you with this question: 'Should people recycle more?' She's excited and ready to start her investigation.
activities.question: What's the best advice you can give Emma?

choices.text: That's a great question! Start collecting data on recycling.
choices.consequence: Not helpful! 'Should people recycle more?' is an opinion question, not testable. You can't measure 'should' scientifically. Emma would struggle to design an investigation.

choices.text: That's not scientific. Pick a different topic completely.
choices.consequence: Too harsh! Emma is passionate about recycling, so we should help her turn this into a scientific question rather than making her abandon the topic.

choices.text: Great topic! Let's make it testable. How about: 'Does pre-sorting recyclables increase the percentage of materials that get recycled?' or 'Which material breaks down fastest in compost?'
choices.consequence: Perfect! You've helped Emma keep her passion for the environment but transformed her opinion question into testable questions with measurable outcomes. Now she can design a real investigation!

choices.text: Just start your experiment and see what happens.
choices.consequence: This doesn't address the problem. Without a testable question, Emma won't know what to investigate or what data to collect. She needs to refine her question first.

activities.title: The Science Fair Dilemma
activities.situation:
You're judging a Year 7 science fair. Three students present their investigation questions:

Student A: 'Which planet is the most interesting?'
Student B: 'How does distance from the Sun affect a planet's surface temperature?'
Student C: 'Why did NASA choose to explore Mars instead of Venus?'

Which student has created the best scientific investigation question?
activities.question: Which question is most suitable for a science investigation?

choices.text: Student A's question about the most interesting planet
choices.consequence: 'Most interesting' is completely subjective - it's an opinion. Different people find different planets interesting for different reasons. This cannot be investigated scientifically.

choices.text: Student B's question about distance and temperature
choices.consequence: Excellent choice! This question has measurable variables (distance, temperature) and can be investigated using data. Student B can collect planetary data and analyze the relationship between these two factors.

choices.text: Student C's question about NASA's decision
choices.consequence: This is about organizational decision-making, not a scientific investigation. While you could research NASA's reasons, this is a historical/policy question, not something Student C can test with evidence.

choices.text: All three questions are equally scientific
choices.consequence: No - only Student B's question is truly testable with measurable data. The others involve opinions (A) or organizational decisions (C) that cannot be investigated scientifically.

stages.title: Writing Testable Questions
stages.description: Master the skill of creating well-formed scientific questions.

activities.title: ‚úçÔ∏è The SMART Question Formula
activities.content:
**How to write a TESTABLE scientific question:**

**1. Identify your variables:**
‚Ä¢ **Independent variable**: What you will change (e.g., temperature, height, material type)
‚Ä¢ **Dependent variable**: What you will measure (e.g., dissolving time, distance, strength)

**2. Use question words that require investigation:**
‚Ä¢ 'How does... affect...?'
‚Ä¢ 'What is the relationship between... and...?'
‚Ä¢ 'Does... change...?'
‚Ä¢ 'Which... has the most/least...?'

**3. Make it measurable:**
‚Ä¢ Include quantities that can be measured
‚Ä¢ Avoid opinion words (best, worst, better, nicest)
‚Ä¢ Use objective terms

**Examples of good format:**
‚Ä¢ 'How does **temperature** (independent) affect **dissolving time** (dependent)?'
‚Ä¢ 'Which **material** (independent) has the **greatest strength** (dependent)?'
‚Ä¢ 'Does **exercise duration** (independent) change **heart rate** (dependent)?'

activities.title: üö´ Words That Signal Non-Testable Questions
activities.content:
**RED FLAG words that usually make questions non-testable:**

**Opinion words:**
‚Ä¢ Best, worst, better, worse
‚Ä¢ Beautiful, ugly, pretty
‚Ä¢ Favorite, least favorite
‚Ä¢ Good, bad
‚Ä¢ Should, ought to

**Why these cause problems:**
These words depend on personal judgment, not measurable evidence.

**How to fix them:**
‚ùå 'Which is the best insulation material?'
‚úÖ 'Which insulation material maintains temperature longest?'

‚ùå 'Should we use solar power?'
‚úÖ 'How does solar panel angle affect energy output?'

‚ùå 'What's the prettiest flower color?'
‚úÖ 'Which flower color attracts the most bees in 10 minutes?'

**Exception:** Sometimes these words CAN be made testable if you define them clearly:
‚Ä¢ 'Best' can mean 'most effective' if you define how you measure effectiveness
‚Ä¢ 'Good' can work if you specify what makes something 'good' with measurements

activities.title: üìñ Summary Notes: Copy to Your Science Book
activities.content:
**Scientific Questions: Testable vs Non-Testable**

**Testable Questions (Scientific):**
‚Ä¢ Can be investigated through measurement and observation
‚Ä¢ Have clear variables (independent and dependent)
‚Ä¢ Produce objective, measurable results
‚Ä¢ Different investigators get similar results
‚Ä¢ Example: 'How does temperature affect dissolving time?'

**Non-Testable Questions (Opinion):**
‚Ä¢ Based on personal preference, beliefs, or values
‚Ä¢ Cannot be answered with measurements
‚Ä¢ No objective way to determine the answer
‚Ä¢ Different people have different valid answers
‚Ä¢ Example: 'Which ice cream flavor is best?'

**How to Write Testable Questions:**
1. Identify your independent variable (what you change)
2. Identify your dependent variable (what you measure)
3. Use question formats:
   ‚Ä¢ 'How does [X] affect [Y]?'
   ‚Ä¢ 'Which [X] has the most/least [Y]?'
   ‚Ä¢ 'Does [X] change [Y]?'
4. Avoid opinion words (best, worst, prettiest, should)
5. Make sure both variables are measurable

**Why This Matters:**
Science requires testable questions because:
‚Ä¢ Other scientists can verify your findings
‚Ä¢ Results are based on evidence, not opinions
‚Ä¢ Knowledge is reliable and builds over time
‚Ä¢ Different people can replicate your investigation

activities.title: The Research Team Challenge
activities.situation:
You're part of a research team investigating climate change effects on local wildlife. Your team proposes these investigation questions:

Question A: 'Is climate change bad for animals?'
Question B: 'How has average temperature changed in our area over the past 50 years?'
Question C: 'Should governments do more to protect wildlife?'
Question D: 'Has the migration timing of local bird species changed since 1990?'
activities.question: Which questions are testable and suitable for your team's investigation? (Choose the best answer)

choices.text: Questions A and C are testable
choices.consequence: No - both use subjective terms ('bad', 'should') that involve value judgments. These are opinion questions about policy and ethics, not testable scientific questions.

choices.text: Questions B and D are testable
choices.consequence: Correct! Both questions involve measurable data (temperature records, migration dates) that can be collected and analyzed. These are well-formed scientific questions your team can investigate.

choices.text: All four questions are equally testable
choices.consequence: Incorrect - A and C involve opinions and values ('bad', 'should') which cannot be measured objectively. Only B and D have clear, measurable variables.

choices.text: Only Question B is testable
choices.consequence: Close! Question B is definitely testable, but Question D is also testable - you can measure when birds migrate by observing and recording their arrival dates. Both B and D work.

activities.title: Fixing the Lab Assignment
activities.situation: Your science teacher gives you this investigation question for your next lab: 'Which is the strongest bridge design?' You realize this question has a problem - 'strongest' isn't clearly defined. Different bridge designs might be strong in different ways.
activities.question: How should you improve this question to make it clearly testable?

choices.text: Keep it the same - 'strongest' is clear enough
choices.consequence: No - 'strongest' could mean: holds most weight, withstands most force, lasts longest, resists bending, etc. Without defining it, you won't know what to measure.

choices.text: Change to: 'Which bridge design is the best?'
choices.consequence: This makes it worse! 'Best' is even more vague than 'strongest.' You still don't know what specific property to measure.

choices.text: Change to: 'Which bridge design supports the greatest mass before collapsing?'
choices.consequence: Perfect! Now 'strongest' is clearly defined as 'supports the greatest mass,' which is measurable. You know exactly what to test and how to measure success.

choices.text: Change to: 'Are bridge designs strong?'
choices.consequence: This is too vague - all bridges have some strength. You're not comparing anything or measuring a specific variable. You need to compare designs and define what you're measuring.

questions.question: A student asks: 'How many moons does Jupiter have?' Is this a good investigative question for a Year 7 science class?
options: Yes - it's about science
No - it's a factual question you can just look up, not an investigation
Yes - you can investigate by using a telescope
No - it's too hard for Year 7
questions.feedback: Correct! While this is science-related, it's not an investigative question - it's a factual question with a known answer you can simply look up. Good investigation questions require you to design an experiment, collect data, and analyze results.

questions.question: Which of these is the most testable question?
options: Why is science important?
Does the angle of sunlight affect solar panel output?
Should everyone learn science?
What's the most interesting science topic?
questions.feedback: Excellent! This question has measurable variables (angle of sunlight, solar panel output) and can be tested through investigation. The others involve opinions or values that cannot be measured objectively.

questions.question: A student writes: 'Are organic vegetables better?' What's the main problem with this question?
options: Organic vegetables aren't scientific
'Better' is undefined - better for what? Nutrition? Taste? Environment? Cost?
The question is too long
You can't measure vegetables
questions.feedback: Perfect! 'Better' needs to be clearly defined with a measurable variable. The student could ask: 'Do organic vegetables contain more Vitamin C?' or 'Do organic vegetables cost more per kilogram?' Each defines what 'better' means measurably.

questions.question: Which improved question best fixes: 'What's the best way to clean water?'
options: Is cleaning water good?
Which cleaning method removes the most bacteria from water samples?
Should we clean water?
Why clean water?
questions.feedback: Excellent! This replaces 'best' with a specific, measurable outcome (removes the most bacteria). Now you know exactly what to measure to determine which method is most effective.

questions.question: A question asks: 'How does music affect plant growth?' What additional information would make this question more precisely testable?
options: Nothing - it's already perfectly testable
Specify: music type, duration, volume, and growth metric (e.g., 'Does 2 hours daily of classical music affect average stem length?')
Just add 'Why does music affect plant growth?'
Change it to 'Should plants listen to music?'
questions.feedback: Perfect! While the original question is testable, being more specific about variables makes the investigation clearer and more reproducible. Specifying music type, duration, volume, and exactly what aspect of growth you're measuring creates a stronger scientific question.

stages.title: Asking the Right Questions
stages.description: Reflect on the importance of testable questions in science.

activities.title: üéØ Why Testable Questions Matter
activities.content:
**The Power of Asking the Right Question**

Science advances through asking questions that can be investigated with evidence. When you can write testable questions, you can:

‚úÖ **Design meaningful investigations** - Know exactly what to measure and how

‚úÖ **Get clear answers** - Measurable results instead of endless opinions

‚úÖ **Build reliable knowledge** - Others can verify your findings

‚úÖ **Solve real problems** - Transform everyday issues into scientific investigations

**Real-World Impact:**

üíä **Medicine**: 'Which drug is better?' became 'Which drug reduces symptoms by the greatest percentage in controlled trials?'

üå± **Agriculture**: 'What's the best fertilizer?' became 'Which fertilizer increases crop yield per hectare most cost-effectively?'

üîã **Technology**: 'Which battery is best?' became 'Which battery maintains voltage longest under constant load?'

**Your Skill:**
Learning to write testable questions is one of the most powerful scientific skills. It transforms vague wondering into clear investigations. Every major scientific discovery started with someone asking the right testable question!

activities.title: Your Science Project
activities.situation: You need to design a science fair project about something you're genuinely interested in. You love skateboarding and want to do your project on that topic. Your initial idea is: 'Which skateboard is the coolest?'
activities.question: How can you transform this interest into a proper scientific investigation question?

choices.text: Keep 'Which skateboard is the coolest?' - it's your opinion that matters
choices.consequence: 'Coolest' is completely subjective. You'd just be sharing your opinion, not conducting a scientific investigation. The judges won't accept this.

choices.text: Change topic completely since skateboarding isn't scientific
choices.consequence: Skateboarding involves lots of science! Don't abandon your interest - transform it into a testable question instead.

choices.text: Ask testable questions like: 'How does wheel diameter affect skateboard speed?' or 'Which deck material absorbs the most impact force?' or 'Does rider position affect turning radius?'
choices.consequence: Perfect! You've kept your passion for skateboarding but created testable questions with clear variables. You can measure speed, force, radius, diameter, etc. Now you have a real scientific investigation!

choices.text: Ask: 'Why are skateboards fun?'
choices.consequence: 'Fun' is subjective and can't be measured objectively. You need to focus on measurable physical properties like speed, friction, force, or distance.

activities.title: ü§î The Ice Cream Question - Revealed!
activities.content:
Remember the ice cream question from the start?

‚ùå **Non-Testable:** 'Which tastes better, chocolate or vanilla?'
‚Ä¢ Based on personal preference
‚Ä¢ No objective way to measure 'better taste'
‚Ä¢ Different people will disagree
‚Ä¢ Opinion, not evidence

‚úÖ **Testable:** 'Which melts faster at 25¬∞C, chocolate or vanilla?'
‚Ä¢ Clear variables: ice cream type (independent), melting time (dependent), temperature (controlled)
‚Ä¢ Can be measured with a timer
‚Ä¢ Different people doing the same test get similar results
‚Ä¢ Evidence-based answer

**The Key Difference:** Science investigates what CAN be measured and observed, not what SHOULD be preferred. Both questions are about ice cream, but only one can be answered with evidence!

Now you can transform any interesting topic into a testable scientific question! üî¨
